hello this is chef john from food wishes

this was the taste which I know sounds
like a major problem but it's not so
let's start at the beginning with this

included some maple syrup as well as
some cold but strong black coffee which
brings us to the ingredient that makes
this a secret breakfast a big little

not realizing that what a horrible

whenever we have what we are going to

it is they generally run about a pound
and are usually fully trimmed and while
not quite as rare or something like a

popular as they should be when you
consider how flavorful affordable and
tender it is and as far as prep goes
since these are about a pound each I
simply like to cut it in half forming
two 8-ounce takes and I find the surface

you can see we're talking about pretty

the flavor and leanness of a top sirloin
but with a tenderness closer to New York
Strip even though it's roughly half the

okay this was like 9 bucks a pound so
for me this is one of the great stake

and I went ahead and poured in my secret

pepper would have made a significantly
better cocktail but the point is we're
going to use the same exact procedure
only using something delicious instead
but anyway we'll go ahead and combine

transfer it into the fridge for a
certain number of hours to be determined

how long you let this in the fridge is
going to depend on exactly which recipe
you choose but no matter which one it is
once you pull it out we're definitely
gonna want to Pat this dry so we'll

then because my brain did not have a ton

as well as some freshly ground black
pepper and we'll do both sides of course
what kind of psychopath would only
season one side of a steak no not even
mark either side and then what we'll do
once we have our steaks dried off and
possibly seasoned up its head outside
and grill these up over high heat which
by the way is not the same thing as a
blazing fire okay so please note our
natural lump charcoal is ashy white and
glowing orange and that's what it should
always look like before you place your
meat down okay so often people blame the
lighter fluid for an off taste when it
really has nothing to do with it it's
actually the people are cooking over
flames and not hot coals so if you only
remember one thing from this video
besides do not use this recipe just let
your charcoal get to this condition
before you try to work with it and then
basically as far as cooking times go
here if you're going with to lay down
steaks you're going to be looking at
about five or six minutes per side for
medium-rare so my usual game plan is let
these go for about four minutes on one
side
and then I will flip those over and give
them about four minutes on the other and
then even though all the experts tell me
not to
I'll kind of start moving it around
flipping them over as I see fit to give
each side another minute or two and
that's basically my method if you can
even call it that okay the experts
quote-unquote tell us not to play with
our meat only turn it once but I'm sorry
I can't just stand in front of cooking

getting close and also another tip for

starts getting forced to the surface
that's always a good clue for me that
